concepts.title: Biological Classification
concepts.content: Classification is the process of grouping organisms based on similarities and differences. Robert Whittaker (1969) proposed the 5-Kingdom system using criteria like complexity of cell structure, complexity of organisms, mode of nutrition, and life style.
keyTakeaways: Whittaker's 5 kingdoms: Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia
Hierarchy: Kingdom -> Phylum -> Class -> Order -> Family -> Genus -> Species
Classification helps in systematic study of vast diversity

concepts.title: The Five Kingdoms
concepts.content: 1. Monera: All unicellular prokaryotic organisms (e.g. Bacteria). 2. Protista: Unicellular eukaryotic organisms (e.g. Amoeba). 3. Fungi: Multicellular saprophytic eukaryotes. 4. Plantae: Autotrophic multicellular eukaryotes. 5. Animalia: Heterotrophic multicellular eukaryotes lacking cell walls.
keyTakeaways: Fungi cell walls are made of Chitin

concepts.title: Classification of Microbes
concepts.content: Microbes are classified into Bacteria, Protozoa, Fungi, Algae, and Viruses. Viruses are considered on the edge of living and non-living. Microbes are measured in micrometers (Œºm) and nanometers (nm).

examples.text: Viruses: Extremely small, need host cell

keyTakeaways: Viruses are 10 to 100 times smaller than bacteria
Most microbes are beneficial, but some are pathogenic
